content.user_title: Build Without Costly Mistakes DeFi Bots
content.value_statement: DeFi trading bots fail in production due to hidden risks that backtests miss. This skill embeds battle-tested patterns from real failures so you can avoid catastrophic losses when building arbitrage, MEV, or automated trading strategies.
actual_capabilities: Identify hidden risks in arbitrage opportunities including reorg, gas spikes, and latency
Calculate realistic expected value accounting for failure rates and competition
Implement Uniswap V3 tick mechanics and concentrated liquidity handling
Configure Flashbots bundle submission with proper simulation and privacy
Apply MEV-Share patterns for backrunning with profit sharing
Design kill switches and circuit breakers for automated trading systems
limitations: Does not execute trades or connect to blockchain networks directly
Does not provide real-time market data or price feeds
Cannot replace testing with actual simulation before going live
References external services but does not implement connectivity

prompt_templates.title: Check Arbitrage Safety
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the DeFi MEV skill to analyze this arbitrage opportunity. What are the hidden risks I should consider? Calculate the realistic expected value accounting for failure rate, reorg probability, and gas costs.

output_examples.input: Analyze this arbitrage: buy ETH on Uniswap V2 at 2000 USDC, sell on Curve stETH pool at 2010 USDC, expected profit 10 USDC per ETH
output: ‚Ä¢ Curve stETH pool may have depeg risk during market stress
‚Ä¢ stETH liquidity concentrated - may not have depth for your trade size
‚Ä¢ 30% failure rate realistic for cross-protocol arb
‚Ä¢ 2% reorg rate means some profitable txs will be uncle'd
‚Ä¢ Gas on success: ~$5-8 for cross-chain swap
RECOMMENDATION: Skip this arb or increase trade size significantly.

best_practices: Always simulate against pending state, not historical blocks, to match production conditions
Factor in 20-30% failure rate and 1-2% reorg rate when calculating expected value
Implement kill switch with capital limits before deploying any trading strategy
Use private mempool submission (Flashbots, MEV-Blocker) to prevent sandwich attacks
anti_patterns: Trusting backtest results without adjusting for latency, gas prediction, and competition
Using public mempool for arbitrage transactions - you will be front-run
Setting slippage too high or too low without understanding liquidity distribution
Deploying without testing on a forked mainnet with realistic conditions first

faq.question: Does this skill connect to blockchain networks?
faq.answer: No. This skill provides knowledge and patterns only. You implement connectivity using standard Web3 libraries in your own code.

faq.question: What failure rates should I assume for arbitrage?
faq.answer: Conservative estimates are 30% failure rate for cross-protocol trades and 1-2% reorg rate on Ethereum mainnet.

faq.question: How does this skill integrate with my existing bot?
faq.answer: Use it during design and development. Prompt for best practices, review patterns, and validate your architecture before implementation.

faq.question: Is my trading data safe?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill only provides guidance. No data leaves your environment and no external connections are made.

faq.question: Why do backtests lie about profitability?
faq.answer: Backtests use perfect historical state. Production has latency, mempool competition, gas uncertainty, and reorgs that historical data cannot capture.

faq.question: How is this different from reading documentation?
faq.answer: This skill embeds hard-won lessons from production failures. Documentation tells you how things work; this tells you what breaks in practice.
